and resilience we were finding that it um impacts farm scale and farmer roles and also farmers satisfaction with their quality of life and their business performance um as people mentioned here scarce lubrical and the seasonal nature of the work can make it really hard to find and keep employees and that redundancy around training can be really tiring for farmers a whole bunch of regulatory uncertainty associated with things like immigration and administration of programs like h2a and perhaps the biggest and most important reason that we all came together was that farmers were telling us that they need to boost their labor management skills um and knowledge and confidence um so um the group of people that mary mentioned earlier all came together we've worked together on two multi-state integrated research and extension projects um and so the research goals are around increasing um understanding in a variety of topic areas and the extension goals are to develop and share new training education and resource education resources to help farmers become more effective labor management managers and in both um projects basically had the same series of activities we did a bunch of interviews and focus groups and serve and some survey work with farmers there was data analysis looking at themes and gaps and then all that combined in the development of tools and details of this but as i bet all of you know it's both complicated and complex um and that's the com the context for how we were thinking about the tools and resources we wanted to put together in this online resource which we're calling the farm labor dashboard so right now what we have is a suite of four interactive tools we have a resource library more tools and resources are coming in the next phase of the project which runs through 2022 and obviously it's online and available 24 7 where farmers and people work with them can access the resources our content focus has really been on helping farmers build um skills knowledge and confidence um to be better managers to help them adopt effective protocols and procedures and to address barriers that they encounter we see that it has as mary mentioned before multiple uses the farmers can access the tools anytime for those of you who are educators you might be interested in incorporating them in your education or outreach programs and business advisors who work one-on-one with farm businesses or a farm team i think also might find some of these resources helpful in moving your clients forward with their labor management so um i'm gonna take you on a quick tour through each of the tools um so the first one is called the labor readiness self-assessment and um basically it focuses on six areas planning recruiting and hiring training and supervision recording record keeping record-keeping taxes and insurance performance reviews and ending employment and the tool provides a summary of farmers strengths it identifies weak links and it suggests resources that will help them address those areas of vulnerability moving forward so it is divided into 21 questions um and in the six critical areas um here are some examples of questions um that that people will be asked to answer and they kind of have the same structure and all of the questions are required so you can kind of look at those and based on how people answer those questions they get a visual representation of their relative strengths and areas where they can build knowledge and skill and in any area where there's a weakness they would get get some recommendations for resources to build um to move forward and we tried very hard in our recommendations both to go from kind of a asset based both you know really recognizing their strengths that they can build on and the positive benefits of improving in the areas that might be seen as weak links so here's one example we have considered the ways that hiring employees will change our roles on the farm so if there doesn't show what they selected but for example if they answered no we need more information or just starting they'll get some recommendations for where to go um and for this particular question the recommendation talks about how learning to be an effective manager typically requires a mental shift in how we see ourselves it recognizes where many farmers are coming from that they got into farming because they like the work of farming but also brings their attention to the challenges and changes in the roles and activities that will be necessary to be an effective farm employer things like they'll be likely to be spending more time managing the work of others teaching and help others to be productive and their own time is going to shift to doing hiring training record-keeping and managing so it's optimistic focuses on learning to enjoy new roles and and it sends people to specific resources so with that i'm going to shift over and let um john lead you help them on their farm is what exactly is this going to cost and you know the first thing for a new employer to learn is that it's not just the hourly wage um i guess this is assuming that they're going to be paying the uh hiring above board and not just paying somebody cash under the table so we built this employee cost estimator to help people understand the full cost of becoming an employer you're going to be having to buy you know some farms have specific tools that are you know these are your tools bob or sally and those are yours so you might be having to buy some additional things for your employees might be having providing food or providing housing for employees you might be offering some bonuses or incentives and there you've got the total cost so what is that total cost so this form is designed to walk people through that process to get to that total cost okay so this is what the estimator looks like online uh the first step is to name the report if you want to save it and then you can plug in a job title for an employee position that you're wanting to hire and then below that is a place to put the hours by month for the different positions that you might be hiring and then there is a second tab there so go ahead beth the second tab in that section after you do the hours is wages and benefits and this is where you start with the hourly rate and then add in all those other items that you might be providing whether it's housing or food or retirement plan perhaps health or other personal insurance bonuses and gifts and a person can use those categories for you know for even things that maybe are different than the titles there as long as they get all the costs and then below that go ahead beth is first there's a spot to you can do multiple employees at the same time so that you see a little button there at the very top that says add another employee so you could add in a whole bunch of employees and do them all at once with different hours and different wages and different benefits and then at the bottom is where you build in the other costs federal unemployment tax workers compensation state unemployment tax all um social security uh medicare all those things now some of these on the federal level are standardized across states some of them are obviously unique to states and so this is a place where a person using this tool very well may have to do some addition some homework on their end in particular in terms of workers compensation workers compensation programs vary widely from state to state in terms of who is required to enroll in workers compensation and the specifics of how those costs are structured and it can be quite challenging to figure that out on your own we encourage people in the video tutorial to contact people like us service providers who work with farmers to answer questions or perhaps even better to contact other farmers who are already employers to find out what are what is a what is a percentage to put in for workers compensation in my state you click submit um and one thing i will note while we're uh transitioning slides is that none of the data that farmers are entering into this site whether it's the excel spreadsheet that they download or this online tool is being collected or analyzed by anyone it just the form gets filled out you can download and print the forms as pdfs or save them on your computer but they're not being saved on our end so this is an example where a person put in uh one field crew person that was working 1280 hours on the farm at a hourly pay rate of 10 and so their you know base wages is 12 800 but then you build in uh the benefits that were being offered they're going to be providing some food um and a bonus or a gift and then building in the fico fuda workers compensation in suda adds in all those numbers and so you have the total cost for the employee for the year and then what i think is an extremely useful number for farmers is the labor cost per hour this is important if you're sending crews out to do work for you it's kind of nice to know what the fully loaded labor cost per hour that you're paying for that crew to do that person to do when you're sending them out to do a job so we call it an estimator because it may may or may not um be completely accurate depending on how well you've done your homework in terms of some of that those factors like workers compensation um but it does provide a way for uh particularly a new employer to get a sense of what the full costs are going to be for them great thanks john so the third tool that is on the dashboard is this job description generator um and basically it helps people um both sort of professionalize and formalize um and um provide consistency in terms of creating job descriptions for the various positions on their farms and there's six basic steps so the step one is that you describe this is what it looks like when you go there you describe the over the positions overall role in the farm business um and so you'll see that there's some sample language there that helps people get started for describing their farm and then the next step is to summarize the major position you can see i've highlighted there um so right now the job description generator is really focused on produce farms and it has um a pretty extensive list of different kinds of tasks that you little plus it can open up and there are a whole bunch of sub um sub categories of tasks that you can select from to create your job description the next step is to think through the qualifications and skills and experience that are required for that position and to list the wages and benefits as well as who the person will report to categorize the type of position and hit submit and when you hit submit um you kind of get a written you get a job description you can download it both as a pdf to use as is or as a word document so you could further edit and modify it um so um so either way works and again like the job like the estimator it doesn't store work so you need to to create a new version you would have to start over our fourth tool is a policy manual generator it's a lot like the job description generator and it provides sample language um to help build a policy manual which um uh you know is considered an uh an important part of um of of having a well-run farm letting your employees know what's expected of them um and having everybody be treated the same and fairly um and um there's a big caveat here about making sure that you check with your state labor department or your own attorney to make sure that the policy manual is in compliance with um your state's laws and best practices um so the policy manual generator is divided into 12 topic areas and each topic area has several items and in each one there's some sample language that um to get you started um so it gives people an idea of of what what to put into those um slots because we found that you know just starting with a blank piece of paper or word document could be a pretty overwhelming place to start for someone in developing their farm policy manual and you can see that there's places there's either xxx or a blank which indicates places where the user needs to fill in the specifics for their farm and again you need to download and print your work and again you get a pdf version or a word version that you can further edit and the final component of the dashboard is this resource library which is searchable using we have this filtering factor so you can search according to topic the material type and the location to look for resources that are pertinent to what you're working on so if for example you chose from the topic of managing employees there's multiple subtopics you could choose supervision and then you could decide what what material um kinds of material there's videos there's fact sheets there's some audio there's um i think maybe whole curriculum so you can choose what you're interested in looking at and then the location is basically the four usda regions so that would be northeast north central south and west so the kinds of materials we have there's um we've
